0: jobs jobs jobs Obama’s Jobs Speech Prompted Some Reactions From Republicans NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR As you may have heard, President Obama got up in front of Congress on Thursday night and semi-nicely asked its members to pass his newly proposed American Jobs Act "right away." His opponents wasted no time in sharing their thoughts with the public: NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR Still high on his petty scheduling victory, John Boehner allowed that the plan "merits consideration": “It’s my hope that we can work together to end the uncertainty facing families and small businesses and create a better environment for long-term economic growth and private-sector job creation." NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR Michele Bachmann went a little rogue and offered an "unsanctioned" televised rebuttal in which she took issue with the president's use of the phrase "political circus": “It was interesting to me that if you look at the president’s remarks, almost out of the gate, the president began by insulting members of Congress ... He invited them to be a part of this address this evening And yet he began with an insult — for a circus tent.” NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR Rick Perry was somehow not convinced: “President Obama’s call for nearly a half-trillion dollars in more government stimulus when America has more than $14 trillion in debt is guided by his mistaken belief that we can spend our way to prosperity." NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR Mitt Romney showed off his edgy side: The usually straitlaced former Massachusetts governor used the evening as an excuse to release some cool video art. NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR Newt Gingrich was pedantic: "[He] had more of a procedural issue with Obama’s speech, in which the president repeatedly called on Congress to approve his American Jobs Act: “I checked with Speaker Boehner’s office. There is no bill.'" NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR Jon Huntsman stuck to Twitter: "@BarackObama's tired rhetoric & failed policies haven't worked. My plan will actually create jobs. Join us." NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR Meanwhile, Herman Cain kept his statement to a Twitter-friendly length: “We waited 30 months for this?” NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR And David Vitter? No miracle occurred, and he did not, in fact, make his football game.
